title: 113_hr4843
content: The Act may be cited as the "Native Contract and Rate Expenditure Act of 2014" or the "Native CARE Act of 2014". Congress finds that federal health services for American Indians and Alaska Natives are necessary due to the government's historical relationship and trust responsibility. The health needs of these populations are severe, with life expectancy 4.2 years lower than the general population. The Indian Health Service and tribal programs provide primary and specialty care services. Purchased/Referred Care programs buy healthcare services from private providers when not available at Indian Health Service or Tribal facilities. Insufficient funds lead to rationed care, delays in treatment, and the need for more costly services. Congress mandated Medicare-participating hospitals to accept patients from these programs at Medicare rates. The Medicare-like rate cap only applies to hospital services, not other Medicare-participating providers. Indian Health Service and Tribal Purchased/Referred Care programs pay full billed charges for non-hospital services, leading to limited treatment options and undesirable health outcomes for American Indians and Alaska Natives. The report found that capping Purchased/Referred Care reimbursement at Medicare-like rates for nonhospital services could double physician services, adding 253,000 patient visits annually. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON CHARGES FOR CERTAIN CONTRACT HEALTH SERVICES PROVIDED TO INDIANS BY MEDICARE PROVIDERS. The amendment to the Social Security Act applies to all providers of services and suppliers, with regulations to be promulgated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The effective date for the amendment is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The Social Security Act is amended to limit charges for certain contract health services provided to Indians by suppliers. Payment is only allowed if the supplier agrees to be a participating provider under the Purchased/Referred Care program funded by the Indian Health Service. The Social Security Act is amended to limit charges for contract health services provided to Indians by suppliers under the Purchased/Referred Care program funded by the Indian Health Service. Payment methodology and rates are regulated by the Secretary, with no reduction in appropriations to the Indian Health Service. The amendment applies to items and services furnished 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the impact of amendments on access to care under the Purchased/Referred Care program of the Indian Health Service. A report containing the study results must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the impact of amendments on access to care under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Section 219(c) of the Act is amended to require biennial reports starting in 2014.
